raw_response:
SUMMARY:
The individual demonstrates a strong preference for entertaining yet thought-provoking media, often rated above 4.5 on average, indicating a consistent satisfaction with their purchases. They appear to appreciate narratives that blend humor and action with moments of introspection, often highlighting themes of adaptation and resilience. This person gravitates towards genres that feature science fiction, historical dramas, and explorations of nuanced human experiences.

Quality is a priority, as evidenced by their high ratings, but they also show a degree of price sensitivity, leaning towards value in entertainment rather than luxury. The reviews suggest a modest tolerance for flaws in storytelling as long as the overall experience remains enjoyable and engaging; a balance between high production values (e.g., seamless special effects) and engaging plots is important.

Frequent mentions of familiar actors and directors indicate a preference for established talent, suggesting comfort in recognizing recognizable storytelling styles. Overall, their behavior indicates they enjoy media that sparks reflection while providing robust entertainment, showcasing a blend of enjoyment in popular culture and critical engagement with deeper themes.

target_interaction.title: Don't give up on it.
target_interaction.text: The first five minutes or so is just wierd music with a black screen. There  is nothing wrong with your TV. This is a slow, slow story, but for scifi and movie geeks like me, it is still fascinating. I was disappointed that the sound track is in simple stereo. But then I realized that surround sound had not been invented in 1968. I was still a bit surprised it had not yet been remastered into 5.1 surround. If you have a home theater system, switch to Dolby PLll mode. Keep in mind that all the special effects were created in the real and captured on film. There was no CGI in 1968. Unlike the Star Wars universe, in this movie, as in reality, there is no sound in space. And the song Daisy, that HAL sings - is a tribute to programmers who, in 1961, created the first synthesized voice on a room-sized IBM computer. It sang Daisy!
description: Supercomputer HAL 9000 guides astronauts on a trip to find the origins of humans.
